overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Selective Service Act of 1948''', also known as the '''Elston Act''', was a major revision of the [[Articles of War of the United States]] enacted June 24, 1948 that established the current implementation of the [[Selective Service System]].
==History== The previous iteration of the Selective Service System was established by the [[Selective Training and Service Act of 1940]]. After two extensions, the Selective Training and Service Act was allowed to expire on March 31, 1947. In 1948, it was replaced by a new and distinct Selective Service System established by this Act. The Selective Service Act of 1948 was originally intended to remain in effect for two years (i.e., until June 24, 1950), but was extended multiple times, usually immediately before its two-year period of effectiveness was due to expire.
The act has had amendments, extensions, and changes of name since 1948, including:
* Extended until July 9, 1950 by {{USStatute|81|572|64|254|1950|06|23}} * Extended until July 9, 1951 by {{USStatute|81|599|64|318|1950|06|30}} * Change of name to the '''Universal Military Training and Service Act''' and extended until July 1, 1953 by {{USStatute|82|51|65|75|1951|06|19}} * Amended by {{USStatute|82|461|66|440|1952|07|07}} * Extended until July 1, 1955 by {{USStatute|83|84|67|86|1953|06|29}} * Extended until July 1, 1959 by {{USStatute|84|118|69|223|1955|06|30}} * Amended by {{USStatute|84|146|69|295|1955|07|12}} * Amended by {{USStatute|84|665|70|509|1956|07|09}} * Amended by {{USStatute|85|62|71|206|1957|06|26}} * Amended by {{USStatute|85|564|72|424|1958|07|28}} * Extended until July 1, 1963 by {{USStatute|86|4|73|13|1959|03|23}} * Amended by {{USStatute|86|632|74|467|1960|07|12}} * Amended by {{USStatute|87|391|75|821|1961|10|04}} * Amended by {{USStatute|87|536|76|167|1962|07|18}} * Extended until July 1, 1967 by {{USStatute|88|2|77|4|1963|03|28}} * Amended by {{USStatute|88|110|77|134|1963|09|03}} * Amended by {{USStatute|88|360|78|296|1964|07|07}} * Amended by {{USStatute|89|152|79|586|1965|08|30}} * Change of name to the '''Military Selective Service Act of 1967''' and extension until July 1, 1971 by {{USStatute|90|40|81|100|1967|06|30}} * Amended by {{USStatute|90|491|82|790|1968|08|17}} * Amended by {{USStatute|91|124|83|220|1969|11|26}} * Change of name to the '''Military Selective Service Act''' and extension until July 1, 1973 by {{USStatute|92|129|85|348|1971|09|28}}

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Mine Safety and Health Administration |logo = Mine Safety and Health Administration emblem.png |logo_width = 200px |formed = 1977 |preceding1 = |jurisdiction = [[Federal government of the United States]] |headquarters = [[Crystal City, Arlington, Virginia]]<ref>{{Cite web| title = MSHA announces new headquarters| accessdate = 2017-12-06| url = http://www.safetyandhealthmagazine.com/articles/12476-msha-announces-new-headquarters}}</ref> |employees = 1,000 |budget = $397 million (2017 budget) |chief1_name = [[David Zatezalo]] |chief1_position = Assistant Secretary of Labor for Mine Safety and Health |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |child1_agency = |website = [http://www.msha.gov/ www.msha.gov] |footnotes = }} The '''Mine Safety and Health Administration''' ('''MSHA''') ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɛ|m|ʃ|ə}}) is an agency of the [[United States Department of Labor]] which administers the provisions of the [[Federal Mine Safety and Health Act]] of 1977 (Mine Act) to enforce compliance with mandatory [[Occupational safety and health|safety and health]] standards as a means to eliminate fatal [[Mining accident|accidents]], to reduce the frequency and severity of nonfatal accidents, to minimize health hazards, and to promote improved safety and health conditions in the nation's mines.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) |location=Washington, DC |url=http://www.msha.gov/MSHAINFO/MISSION.HTM |title=MSHA's Mission |accessdate= 2010-09-05}}</ref> MSHA carries out the mandates of the Mine Act at all [[mining]] and [[mineral processing]] operations in the United States, regardless of size, number of employees, commodity mined, or method of extraction. [[David Zatezalo]] is Assistant Secretary of Labor for Mine Safety and Health, and the head of MSHA.
MSHA is organized into several divisions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msha.gov/programs/programs.htm |title=MSHA Program Areas |publisher=msha.gov |accessdate= 2010-09-05}}</ref> The Coal Mine Safety and Health division is divided into 12 districts covering [[coal mining]] in different portions of the United States. The Metal-Nonmetal Mine Safety and Health division covers six regions of the United States.
== History ==
=== Early legislation === In 1891, [[United States Congress|Congress]] passed the first federal statute governing mine safety. The 1891 law was relatively modest legislation that applied only to mines in [[Territories of the United States|U.S. territories]], and, among other things, established minimum [[Underground mine ventilation|ventilation]] requirements at underground coal mines and prohibited operators from employing children under 12 years of age.<ref>Mine Safety and Health Administration. {{cite web |url=http://www.msha.gov/mshainfo/mshainf2.htm | title=History of Mine Safety and Health Legislation |accessdate=2012-07-12}}</ref>
In 1910, Congress established the [[United States Bureau of Mines|Bureau of Mines]] as a new agency in the [[Department of the Interior]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Page |first=Arthur W. |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=March 1912 |title=Safety First Underground: The New Bureau Of Mines And Its Life Saving Campaign In The Coal Fields |journal=[[World's Work|The World's Work: A History of Our Time]] |volume=XXIII |issue= |pages=549–563 |id= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Vv--PfedzLAC&pg=PA549|accessdate=2009-07-10 |quote= }}</ref> The Bureau was charged with the responsibility to conduct research and to reduce accidents in the coal mining industry, but was given no inspection authority until 1941, when Congress empowered federal inspectors to enter mines.<ref>P.L. 77-49, 55 Stat. 177.</ref> In 1947, Congress authorized the formulation of the first [[code of federal regulations]] for mine safety.<ref>P.L. 80-328, 61 Stat. 725.</ref>
The [[Federal Coal Mine Safety Act of 1952]] provided for annual inspections in certain underground coal mines, and gave the Bureau limited enforcement authority, including power to issue violation notices and imminent danger withdrawal orders.<ref>P.L. 82-552, 66 Stat. 692, July 16, 1952.</ref> The 1952 Act also authorized the assessment of [[Civil penalty|civil penalties]] against mine operators for noncompliance with withdrawal orders or for refusing to give inspectors access to mine property, although no provision was made for monetary penalties for noncompliance with the safety provisions. In 1966, Congress extended coverage of the 1952 Coal Act to all underground coal mines.<ref>P.L. 89-376, Mar. 26, 1966.</ref>
The first federal statute directly regulating non-coal mines did not appear until the passage of the Federal Metal and Nonmetallic Mine Safety Act of 1966.<ref>P.L. 89-577, Sept. 16, 1966.</ref> The 1966 Act provided for the promulgation of standards, many of which were advisory, and for inspections and investigations; however, its enforcement authority was minimal.
=== Coal Act === The [[Coal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1969]], generally referred to as the Coal Act, was more comprehensive and more stringent than any previous federal legislation governing the mining industry.<ref>P.L. 91-173, Dec. 30, 1969.</ref> The Coal Act included [[Surface mining|surface]] as well as underground coal mines within its scope, required two annual inspections of every surface coal mine and four at every underground coal mine, and dramatically increased federal enforcement powers in coal mines. The Coal Act also required monetary penalties for all violations, and established criminal penalties for knowing and willful violations. The safety standards for all coal mines were strengthened, and health standards were adopted. The Coal Act included specific procedures for the development of improved mandatory [[Occupational safety and health|health and safety]] standards, and provided compensation for miners who were totally and permanently disabled by the progressive respiratory disease caused by the inhalation of fine [[coal dust]] [[pneumoconiosis]] or "black lung."
In 1973, the [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]], through administrative action, created the [[Mining Enforcement and Safety Administration]] (MESA) as a new departmental agency separate from the Bureau of Mines. MESA assumed the safety and health enforcement functions formerly carried out by the Bureau to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest between the enforcement of mine safety and health standards and the Bureau's responsibilities for mineral resource development. (MESA was the predecessor organization to MSHA, prior to March 9, 1978.)
=== Mine Act and creation of MSHA === More recently, Congress passed the [[Federal Mine Safety and Health Act]] of 1977, the legislation which currently governs MSHA's activities.<ref>P.L. 95-164, Nov. 9, 1977.</ref> The Mine Act amended the 1969 Coal Act in a number of significant ways, and consolidated all federal health and safety regulations of the mining industry, coal as well as non-coal mining, under a single statutory scheme. The Mine Act strengthened and expanded the rights of miners, and enhanced the protection of miners from retaliation for exercising such rights. Mining fatalities dropped sharply under the Mine Act from 272 in 1977 to 45 in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title = Mine Fatalities – 100 Years of Progress (1915-2015)|url = http://www.minesafetycenter.com/mine-fatalities-progress/|website = Mine Safety Center MSHA Blog|accessdate = 15 December 2015}}</ref> The Mine Act also transferred responsibility for carrying out its mandates from the Department of the Interior to the Department of Labor, and created MSHA. Additionally, the Mine Act established the independent [[Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Commission]] to provide for independent review of the majority of MSHA's enforcement actions.
Congress passed the Mine Improvement and New Emergency Response Act (MINER Act) in 2006.<ref>P.L. 109-236, 120 Stat. 493, June 15, 2006.</ref> The MINER Act amended the Mine Act to require mine-specific emergency response plans in underground coal mines; added new regulations regarding mine rescue teams and sealing of abandoned areas; required prompt notification of mine accidents; and enhanced civil penalties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msha.gov/MSHAINFO/MSHAINF2.HTM |title=History of Mine Safety and Health Legislation |publisher=Msha.gov |accessdate= 2010-09-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msha.gov/MinerAct/MinerActSingleSource.asp |title=The MINER Act: Single Source Page |publisher=Msha.gov |accessdate=2010-09-05}}</ref>
== Modern regulations == Modern mining regulation in the [[United States]] is carried out by MSHA and governed by The [[Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977]] and [http://www.msha.gov/regs/complian/ppm/pmvol3b.htm MSHA's Program Policy Manual Volume III].
On January 27, 2012 as required under the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]], the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] adopted final rules which require covered SEC-reporting issuers that are “operator(s)” (or that has a subsidiary that is an “operator”) of a “coal or other mine” to disclose certain mine safety violations, citations and orders and related matters for each coal or other mine that they operate.<ref>{{cite web |title=SEC Adopts Mine Safety Disclosure Rules |url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/sec-adopts-mine-safety-disclosure-rules |publisher= Andrews Kurth LLP|work=The [[National Law Review]]|date=2012-01-11|accessdate=2012-02-23}}</ref> Covered mine “operator(s)” are also required to file a current report on Form 8-K to disclose the receipt of certain orders and notices from the U.S. Labor Department’s Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) related to a coal or other mine that they operate.{{Relevance-inline|date=March 2012}}
=== Hearing Conservation === MSHA regulations state an action level (AL) and a permissible exposure level (PEL) which set standards for when a hearing conservation program need to be put into place. The action level is an 8-hour time-weighted average sound level (TWA<sub>8</sub>) of 85 dBA, or a dose of 50%, integrating all sound levels from 80 dBA to at least 130 dBA. A permissible exposure level (PEL) is a TWA<sub>8</sub> of 90 dBA, or equivalently, a dose of 100% , integrating all sound levels from 90 dBA to at least 140 dBA. In the hearing conservation program the company must try all feasible engineering and administrative controls before they provide hearing protective devices.<ref>{{Citation|last=Royster|first=Larry H.|title=Appendix I: Department Of Labor Occupational Noise Exposure Standard|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.3320/978-1-931504-14-0.a1|work=Noise Vibration Problem-Solution Workbook|pages=A1–A8|publisher=American Industrial Hygiene Association|isbn=9781931504140|access-date=2018-12-02|last2=Royster|first2=Julia Doswell}}</ref>
If a miner's noise exposure exceeds the PEL despite the use of all feasible engineering and administrative controls, Section 62.130 requires the company to:
· continue to use the controls to maintain the miner's exposure as low as feasible;
· provide and require the use of hearing protectors;
· enroll the miner in a hearing conservation program; and
· post procedures for administrative controls on the mine bulletin board and provide a copy to the affected miners.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arlweb.msha.gov/regs/complian/guides/noise/g3appendixb.htm|title=MSHA - Noise Regulations - Compliance Guide to MSHA's Occupational Noise Exposure Standard - Appendix B|website=arlweb.msha.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>
Although hearing protectors must be provided and used if the engineering and administrative controls fail to reduce the miner's noise exposure to the PEL, they are not accepted in lieu of such controls.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arlweb.msha.gov/regs/30cfr/|title=Title 30 Code of Federal Regulations|website=arlweb.msha.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>
in regards to hearing protectors OSHA requires the company to provide hearing protectors to any miner whose noise exposure equals or exceeds the action level. The miner must also be trained on the "types of hearing protectors, the value of wearing hearing protection and of audiometric tests"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arlweb.msha.gov/regs/30cfr/|title=Title 30 Code of Federal Regulations|website=arlweb.msha.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>. The company must also provide the miner a choice of hearing protectors, including at least two muff type and two plug type hearing protectors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arlweb.msha.gov/regs/30cfr/|title=Title 30 Code of Federal Regulations|website=arlweb.msha.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>
The hearing protectors that you provide must be "in good condition, fitted, and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arlweb.msha.gov/regs/complian/guides/noise/guide303.htm|title=MSHA - Noise Regulations - Compliance Guide to MSHA's Occupational Noise Exposure Standard - Main Document|website=arlweb.msha.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>. If a miner's noise exposure exceeds the dual hearing protector level, the company must provide both a muff type and plug type protector<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://arlweb.msha.gov/regs/complian/guides/noise/guide303.htm|title=MSHA - Noise Regulations - Compliance Guide to MSHA's Occupational Noise Exposure Standard - Main Document|website=arlweb.msha.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref>.
=== Accidents and Accident Reporting ===
Mine operators are required by law to report all mining accidents within 15 minutes of when the operator knew or should have known about the accident. <ref>https://www.msha.gov/about/contact/emergencies</ref>
Immediately reportable accidents and injuries are: # A death of an individual at a mine; # An injury to an individual at a mine which has a reasonable potential to cause death; # An entrapment of an individual for more than thirty minutes; # An unplanned inundation of a mine by a liquid or gas; # An unplanned ignition or explosion of gas or dust; # An unplanned [[mine fire]] not extinguished within 30 minutes of discovery; # An unplanned ignition or explosion of a [[Explosive material|blasting agent or explosive]]; # An unplanned [[Cave-in|roof fall]] at or above the anchorage zone in active workings where roof bolts are in use; or, an unplanned roof or rib fall in active workings that impairs ventilation or impedes passage; # A [[Outburst (mining)|coal]] or [[rock outburst]] that causes withdrawal of miners or which disrupts regular mining activity for more than one hour; # An unstable condition at an [[Coal slurry|impoundment]], [[Waste|refuse]] pile, or [[Spoil tip|culm bank]] which requires emergency action in order to prevent failure, or which causes individuals to evacuate an area; or, failure of an impoundment, refuse pile or [[culm bank]]; # Damage to [[Hoist (mining)|hoisting equipment]] in a shaft or slope which endangers an individual or which interferes with use of the equipment for more than thirty minutes; and # An event at a mine which causes death or bodily injury to an individual not at the mine at the time the event occurs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msha.gov/codeaphone/ReportableInjury.asp |title=Immediately Reportable Accidents and Injuries |publisher=Msha.gov |accessdate=2010-09-05}}</ref>
Statistical analyses performed by MSHA show that between 1990 and 2004, the industry cut the rate of injuries (a measure comparing the rate of incidents to overall number of employees or hours worked) by more than half and fatalities by two-thirds following three prior decades of steady improvement.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_cfJCQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA10&dq=between%201990%20and%202004%2C%20the%20industry%20cut%20the%20rate%20of%20injuries&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q&f=false Us Federal Mine Safety and Health Review Administration Handbook]: Strategic Information and Regulations (World Business and Investment Library) </ref>
=== MSHA Inspections ===
MSHA employs nearly one safety inspector for every four coal mines. Underground coal mines are thoroughly inspected at least four times annually by MSHA inspectors. In addition, miners can report violations, and request additional inspections. Miners with such concerns for their work safety cannot be penalized with any threat to the loss of employment.
Additionally, the Mine Safety and Health Act authorizes the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] (NIOSH), part of the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] under the [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] to develop recommendations for mine health standards for the Mine Safety and Health Administration; administer a medical surveillance program for miners, including [[Chest radiograph|chest X-rays]] to detect [[pneumoconiosis]] (black lung disease) in coal miners; conduct on-site investigations in mines; and test and certify [[personal protective equipment]] and hazard-measurement instruments.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/about.html|title=About NIOSH|accessdate=2007-10-28|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025061315/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/about.html|archive-date=2007-10-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>

page.title: Minimum wage in the United States

revision.text:
[[File:US minimum wage map.svg|thumb|upright=1.4|Minimum wage by [[U.S. state]] and [[Territories of the United States|territory]] versus the federal rate of $7.25 per hour as of January 1, 2018:{{Cite web|url=https://www.dol.gov/whd/minwage/america.htm|title=Minimum Wage Laws in the States – Wage and Hour Division (WHD) – U.S. Department of Labor|website=www.dol.gov|access-date=2017-11-25}}
{{Legend inline |#008001|Higher}} {{Legend inline |#0000FE|Same}} {{Legend inline |#FE0000|Lower}} {{Legend|#FFFF00|No state minimum wage lawThe federal minimum wage applies to states with no set minimum wage and to most workers in states with lower minimum wages.}} ]] The '''minimum wage in the United States''' is set by [[US labor law]] and a range of state and local laws.{{cite book|last1=Bradley|first1=David H.|title=State Minimum Wages: An Overview|date=February 3, 2016|publisher=Congressional Research Service|location=Washington, DC|url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43792.pdf|accessdate=31 January 2018}} Employers generally have to pay workers the highest [[minimum wage]] prescribed by federal, state, and local law. Since July 24, 2009, the [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]] has mandated a nationwide minimum wage of $7.25 per hour.United States Department of Labor, https://www.dol.gov/general/topic/wages/minimumwage. Retrieved November 20, 2017 As of January 2018, there were 29 states with a minimum wage higher than the federal minimum.{{Cite news|url=https://www.epi.org/minimum-wage-tracker/|title=Minimum Wage Tracker|work=Economic Policy Institute|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} From 2017 to 2018, eight states increased their minimum wage levels through automatic adjustments, while increases in eleven other states occurred through referendum or legislative action.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/labor-and-employment/state-minimum-wage-chart.aspx|title=State Minimum Wages {{!}} 2017 Minimum Wage by State|last=Legislatures|first=National Conference of State|website=www.ncsl.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-20}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nelp.org/publication/raises-from-coast-to-coast-in-2018-minimum-wage-increases/|title=Raises from Coast to Coast in 2018: Workers in 18 States and 19 Cities and Counties Seeing Minimum Wage Increases on January 1 |work=National Employment Law Project|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}} Using 2018 [[Constant dollars|inflation-adjusted dollars]], the federal minimum wage peaked at $11.77 per hour in 1968.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/data/inflation_calculator.htm|title=CPI Inflation Calculator|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bls.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-14|quote=Feb, 1968 – $1.60 converted to May, 2018 dollars → $11.77}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.rand.org/blog/2016/09/working-for-725-an-hour-exploring-the-minimum-wage.html|title=Working for $7.25 an Hour: Exploring the Minimum Wage Debate|website=www.rand.org|language=en|others=Wenger, Jeffrey B.|access-date=2017-12-14}} If the minimum wage in 1968 had kept up with labor's productivity growth, it would have reached $19.33 in 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-higher-the-federal-minimum-wage-should-be-2017-12|title=Low-wage workers will get paid more in 18 states in 2018 – but they could earn much more if the federal minimum wage had kept up with the economy|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-12-21|language=en}} There is a racial difference in support for a higher minimum wage with most Black and Latino individuals supporting a $15.00 federal minimum wage, and 54% of Whites opposing it.[http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2017/01/04/5-facts-about-the-minimum-wage/ 5 facts about the minimum wage] Drew DeSilver, Pew Research Center, January 4, 2017 In 2015, about 3% of White, Asian, and Latino workers earned the federal minimum wage or less. Amongst Black workers, the percentage was about 4%.{{cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/opub/reports/minimum-wage/2015/home.htm|title=Characteristics of minimum wage workers, 2015 : BLS Reports: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|website=Bls.gov|accessdate=18 October 2017}} ==History== {{quote box | quote = It seems to me to be equally plain that no business which depends for existence on paying less than living wages to its workers has any right to continue in this country. | source = — [[President Franklin D. Roosevelt]], 1933{{cite news |last=Tritch |first=Teresa |title=F.D.R. Makes the Case for the Minimum Wage |url=http://takingnote.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/07/f-d-r-makes-the-case-for-the-minimum-wage/ |date=March 7, 2014 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=March 7, 2014 }}{{Cite web|url=http://docs.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/odnirast.html|title=Franklin Roosevelt's Statement on the National Industrial Recovery Act|last=|first=|date=June 16, 1933|website=Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum Our Documents|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-17}} | width = 260px }} Minimum wage legislation emerged at the [[Gilded Age|end of the nineteenth century]] from the desire to end [[Sweatshop#History|sweated labor]] which had developed in the [[Second Industrial Revolution|wake of industrialization]].{{Cite book|url=https://fraser.stlouisfed.org/title/4055|title=Minimum Wage Legislation in Various Countries: Bulletin of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, No. 467|last=Broda|first=Rudolf|last2=United States. Bureau of Labor Statistics|date=December 1928|publisher=G.P.O.|year=|isbn=|series=Bulletin of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics|location=|pages=8}} [[Sweatshop]]s employed large numbers of women and young workers, paying them what were considered [[Living wage|nonliving wages]] that did not allow workers to afford the necessaries of life.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/33983425|title=The quest for a living wage : the history of the federal minimum wage program|last=Willis J.|first=Nordlund|date=|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=1997|isbn=9780313264122|location=Westport, Conn.|pages=2|oclc=33983425}} Besides substandard wages, sweating was also associated with long work hours and unsanitary work conditions.{{Cite journal|last=Hammond|first=Matthew B.|date=1913|title=The Minimum Wage in Great Britain and Australia|journal=The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science|volume=48|pages=26|via=|jstor=1012009}} From the 1890s to the 1920s, during the [[Progressive Era]], a time of social activists and political reform across the United States, progressive reformers, women's organizations, religious figures, academics, and politicians all played an important role in getting state minimum wage laws passed throughout the United States.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/700688619|title=Bound by Our Constitution : Women, Workers, and the Minimum Wage.|last=Vivien.|first=Hart,|date=2001|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=|isbn=9781400821563|location=Princeton|pages=67|oclc=700688619}} The first successful attempts at using minimum wage laws to ameliorate the problem of nonliving wages occurred in the [[Victoria (Australia)|Australian state of Victoria]] in 1896.{{Cite journal|last=Webb|first=Sidney|date=1912|title=The Economic Theory of a Legal Minimum Wage|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=20|issue=10|pages=973|via=|doi=10.1086/252125|jstor=1820545}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gzurqlZpyfcC&pg=PA1&dq=the+history+of+%22minimum+wage%22+law#v=onepage&q=the%20history%20of%20%22minimum%20wage%22%20law&f=false|title=Minimum wage fixing : an international review of practices and problems|last=Starr|first=Gerald|publisher=International Labour Office|year=1993|isbn=9789221025115|edition=2nd impression (with corrections)|location=Geneva|page=1}} Factory inspector reports and newspaper reporting on the conditions of sweated labor in [[Melbourne]], Victoria led in 1895 to the formation of the [[National Anti-Sweating League]] which pushed the government aggressively to deal legislatively with the problem of substandard wages.{{Cite journal|last=Hammond|first=Matthew B.|date=1913|title=The Minimum Wage in Great Britain and Australia|journal=The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science|volume=48|pages=27|via=|jstor=1012009}} The government, following the recommendation of the Victorian [[Chief Secretary (British Empire)|Chief Secretary]] [[Alexander Peacock]], established wage boards which were tasked with establishing minimum wages in the labor trades which suffered from nonlivable wages. During the same time period, campaigns against sweated labor were occurring in the United States and England.{{Cite book|url=https://fraser.stlouisfed.org/title/4055|title=Minimum Wage Legislation in Various Countries: Bulletin of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, No. 467|last=Broda|first=Rudolf|last2=United States. Bureau of Labor Statistics|date=December 1928|publisher=G.P.O.|year=|isbn=|series=Bulletin of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics|location=|pages=11}} === Progressive Era === In the United States in 1890, a group of concerned female reformers who wanted to improve the harsh conditions of sweated workers formed the Consumer's League of the City of New York. The consumer group sought to improve working conditions by boycotting products which were made under sweated conditions and did not conform to a code of "fair house" standards drawn up by them. Similar, consumer leagues formed throughout the United States, and in 1899, they united under the [[National Consumers League|National Consumer League]] (NCL) parent organization.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42072067|title=The politics of the minimum wage|last=Jerold L.,|first=Waltman|date=2000|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252025457|location=Urbana|pages=11|oclc=42072067}} Consumer advocacy, however, was extremely slow at changing conditions in the sweated industries. When NCL leaders in 1908 went to an international [[anti-sweatshop movement|anti-sweatshop]] conference in [[Geneva]], Switzerland and were introduced to [[Australian labour movement|Australian minimum wage legislation]], which had successfully dealt with sweated labor, they came home believers and made minimum wage legislation part of their national platform.{{Cite book|url=|title=Bound by Our Constitution : Women, Workers, and the Minimum Wage|last=Vivien|first=Hart|date=2001|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=|isbn=9781400821563|location=Princeton|pages=63|oclc=700688619}}[[Image:1912 Lawrence Textile Strike 1.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Massachusetts militiamen with fixed bayonets surround a group of peaceful strikers during the [[Lawrence textile strike]] which proved pivotal in the passage of the first U.S. minimum wage legislation (1912)]] In 1910, in conjunction with advocacy work led by [[Florence Kelley]] of the National Consumer League, the [[Women's Trade Union League]] (WTLU) of Massachusetts under the leadership of Elizabeth Evans took up the cause of minimum wage legislation in [[Massachusetts]]. Over the next two years, a coalition of social reform groups and labor advocates in Boston pushed for minimum wage legislation in the state.{{Cite book|url=|title=Bound by Our Constitution : Women, Workers, and the Minimum Wage|last=Vivien|first=Hart|date=2001|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=|isbn=9781400821563|location=Princeton|pages=68|oclc=700688619}} On June 4, 1912, Massachusetts passed the first minimum wage legislation in the United States, which established a state commission for recommending non-compulsory minimum wages for women and children.{{Cite journal|last=Kelley|first=Florence|date=1912|title=Minimum-Wage Laws|jstor=1820546|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=20|issue=10|pages=999–1010}}http://archives.lib.state.ma.us/actsResolves/1912/1912acts0706.pdf The passage of the bill was significantly assisted by the [[1912 Lawrence textile strike|Lawrence textile strike]] which had raged for ten weeks at the beginning of 1912. The strike brought national attention to the plight of the low wage textile workers, and pushed the state legislatures, who feared the magnitude of the strike, to enact progressive labor legislation.{{Cite book|url=|title=Bound by Our Constitution : Women, Workers, and the Minimum Wage|last=Vivien|first=Hart|date=2001|publisher=Princeton University Press|year=|isbn=9781400821563|location=Princeton|pages=70–71|oclc=700688619}} By 1923, fifteen [[U.S. state]]s and the [[District of Columbia]] had passed [[minimum wage law]]s, with pressure being placed on state legislatures by the National Consumers League in a coalition with other women's voluntary associations and organized labor.William P. Quigley, "'A Fair Day's Pay For A Fair Day's Work': Time to Raise and Index the Minimum Wage", 27 ''St. Mary's L. J.'' 513, 516 (1996){{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Protecting_Soldiers_and_Mothers.html?id=p1VHAAAAMAAJ|title=Protecting soldiers and mothers: the political origins of social policy in the United States|last=Skocpol|first=Theda|date=1992|publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press|year=|isbn=9780674717657|location=|pages=|language=en|chapter=Chapter 7: Safeguarding the "Mothers of the Race": Protective Legislation for Women Workers}} The [[United States Supreme Court]] of the [[Lochner era|''Lochner'' era]] (1897–1937), however, consistently invalidated labor regulation laws. Advocates for state minimum wage laws hoped that they would be upheld under the precedent of ''[[Muller v. Oregon]]'' (1908), which upheld maximum working hours laws for women on the grounds that women required special protection that men did not. The Supreme Court, however, did not extend this principle to minimum wage laws.{{rp|518}} The court ruled in ''[[Adkins v. Children's Hospital]]'' (1923) that the District of Columbia's minimum wage law was unconstitutional, because the law interfered with the ability of employers to [[Freedom of contract|freely negotiate wage contracts]] with employees. The court also noted that women did not require anymore special protection by the law, following the passage in 1920 of the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Nineteenth Amendment]], which gave women the right to vote and equal legal status.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/25409018|title=Protecting soldiers and mothers : the political origins of social policy in the United States|last=Theda|first=Skocpol|date=1992|publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press|year=|isbn=0674717651|location=Cambridge, Mass.|pages=423|oclc=25409018}} === New Deal === In 1933, the [[Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt administration]] during the [[New Deal]] made the first attempt at establishing a national minimum wage regiment with the [[National Industrial Recovery Act]], which set minimum wage and maximum hours on an industry and regional basis. The Supreme Court, however, in ''[[Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States]]'' (1935) ruled the act unconstitutional, and the minimum wage regulations were abolished.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DF_lCgAAQBAJ|title=The Minimum Wage: A Reference Handbook|last=Levin-Waldman|first=Oren M.|date=2015-12-01|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=|isbn=9781440833953|location=|pages=12–13|language=en}} Two years later after President Roosevelt's overwhelming [[Presidential election of 1936|reelection in 1936]] and [[Judicial Procedures Reform Bill of 1937|discussion of judicial reform]], the Supreme Court took up the issue of labor legislation again in ''[[West Coast Hotel Co. v. Parrish]]'' (1937) and upheld the constitutionality of minimum wage legislation enacted by [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] state and overturned the ''Adkins'' decision which marked the end of the ''Lochner'' era.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mQBkiNPupvsC|title=The Case for the Living Wage|last=Waltman|first=Jerold L.|date=2004|publisher=Algora Publishing|year=|isbn=9780875863023|location=|pages=184|language=en}} In 1938, the minimum wage was re-established pursuant to the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]], this time at a uniform rate of $0.25 per hour ($4.78 in 2017 dollars{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/data/inflation_calculator.htm|title=CPI Inflation Calculator|last=|first=|date=|work=U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|accessdate=21 August 2017}}). The Supreme Court upheld the Fair Labor Standards Act in ''[[United States v. Darby Lumber Co.]]'' (1941), holding that Congress had the power under the [[Commerce Clause]] to regulate employment conditions.{{caselaw source |case=''U.S. v. Darby Lumber Co.'', 312 U.S. 100 (1941) |findlaw=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?navby=CASE&court=US&vol=312&page=100 |justia=http://supreme.justia.com/us/312/100/case.html}} The 1938 minimum wage law only applied to "employees engaged in interstate commerce or in the production of goods for interstate commerce," but in amendments in 1961 and 1966, the federal minimum wage was extended (with slightly different rates) to employees in large retail and service enterprises, local transportation and construction, state and local government employees, as well as other smaller expansions; a grandfather clause in 1990 drew most employees into the purview of federal minimum wage policy, which now set the wage at $3.80.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dol.gov/whd/minwage/chart.htm#fn2|title=Minimum Wage – Wage and Hour Division (WHD) – U.S. Department of Labor|website=Dol.gov|access-date=2017-04-16}} ==Legislation== [[File:Fight for $15 on 4-15 (16975968559).jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|[[Living wage]] rally and march for a $15 per hour minimum wage and [[trade unions|union rights]] in New York City on April 15, 2015.]] The federal minimum wage in the United States was reset to its current rate of $7.25 per hour in July 2009. Some U.S. territories (such as [[American Samoa]]) are exempt. Some types of labor are also exempt: Employers may pay [[tip (gratuity)|tipped labor]] a minimum of $2.13 per hour, as long as the hour wage plus tip income equals at least the minimum wage. Persons under the age of 20 may be paid $4.25 an hour for the first 90 calendar days of employment (sometimes known as a youth, teen, or training wage) unless a higher state minimum exists.{{cite web | title = Fact Sheet #32: Youth Minimum Wage – Fair Labor Standards Act | publisher = U.S. Department of Labor – Wage and Hour Division | url = http://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/whdfs32.pdf | accessdate = 2013-09-25 }} The 2009 increase was the last of three steps of the [[Fair Minimum Wage Act of 2007]], which was signed into law as a [[Rider (legislation)|rider]] to the [[U.S. Troop Readiness, Veterans' Care, Katrina Recovery, and Iraq Accountability Appropriations Act, 2007]], a bill that also contained almost $5 billion in tax cuts for small businesses. === Inflation indexing === Some politicians in the United States advocate linking the minimum wage to the [[consumer price index]], thereby increasing the wage automatically each year based on increases to the consumer price index. Linking the minimum wage to the consumer price index avoids the erosion of the [[purchasing power]] of the minimum wage with time because of [[inflation]]. In 1998 [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state became the first state to approve consumer price indexing for its minimum wage.{{Cite news|url=https://www.epi.org/publication/webfeatures_snapshots_20051221/|title=Indexing the minimum wage for inflation|work=Economic Policy Institute|access-date=2018-03-20|language=en-US}} In 2003 [[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]] and [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]] were the first cities to approve consumer price indexing for their minimum wage.{{Cite web|url=https://sfgov.org/olse/san-francisco-historical-minimum-wage-rates|title=San Francisco Historical Minimum Wage Rates {{!}} Office of Labor Standards Enforcement|website=sfgov.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-19}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.epi.org/minimum-wage-tracker/#/min_wage/New%20Mexico/Santa%20Fe%20City|title=Minimum Wage Tracker|work=Economic Policy Institute|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-US}} [[Oregon]] and [[Florida]] were the next states to link their minimum wages to the consumer price index. Later in 2006, voters in six states ([[Arizona]], [[Colorado]], [[Missouri]], [[Montana]], [[Nevada]], and [[Ohio]]) approved statewide increases in the state minimum wage. The amounts of these increases ranged from $1 to $1.70 per hour, and all increases were designed to annually index to inflation.{{cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/views06/1111-24.htm|title=ACORN and Unions Increase Working Wages Across the Country|last=|first=|date=2006-11-11|work=|publisher=Common Dreams|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130618163414/http://www.commondreams.org/views06/1111-24.htm|archivedate=2013-06-18|deadurl=yes}} As of 2018, the minimum wage is indexed to inflation in 17 states. === Living wage protests === {| class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin:0 0 1em 1em; font-size: 100%; " |- |+ Living wage to cover basic needs in select U.S. cities (2017)The living wage per hour for an individual is calculated for a family unit with two working adults and two children.
